text: The most instantly recognisable Palace in the world. The Royal Standard, (the flag of heraldic lions and symbo harp-strings that signals the Monarch's presence), flutte on the roof.
We're in a state room at Buckingham Palace. A TV plays in corner..
..here's Tony Blair, just 43 years old, arriving at the polling station of his constituency in Sedgefield.."

QUEEN ELIZABETH II, wearing formal robes of the Garter, i posing for an official portrait by an elderly black PORTR ARTIST, (representative, one assumes, of one of the many Charities of which she is patron)..
Have you voted yet, Mr Crawford?
(proudly dabbing palette) Yes, Ma'am. I was there when they opened. First in line. Seven o'clock.
If he wins, he'll be the youngest Prime Minister in almost two hundred years.."
He straightens..
And I don't mind telling you, it wasn't for Mr Blair.
Not a moderniser, then?
Certainly not. We're in danger of losing too much that's good about this country as it is.
"The only questions that still remain: how big will his landslide be? And how extensive, how sweeping will the modernisation programme be that he ushers in?"
Hmm.
The QUEEN watches as he paints..
I rather envy you being able to vote. (a beat) Not the actual ticking of the box, although, I suppose, it would be nice to experience that ONCE. (a beat) But the sheer joy of being partial.
Yes..
The ARTIST squints as he scrutinises the canvass..
One forgets that as Sovereign, you are not entitled to vote.
No.
Still, you won't catch me feeling sorry for you. You might not be allowed to vote, Ma'am.. (a beat) But it IS your Government.
Yes.
The QUEEN raises her eyebrow..
I suppose that is some consolation.
The QUEEN's face. Fast asleep. It's shortly before 8.00 a Daylight filters through the curtains. As does something else.. The stirring sound of bagpipes..

The inner courtyard of Buckingham Palace. In a ritual unchanged since Queen Victoria, a uniformed PIPER, wearin kilt of Ancient Hunting Stuart tartan, marches under her Majesty's windows, playing the bagpipes. t's her morning alarm call, and it's the way she wakes up wherever she is - anywhere in the world.
Darkness. A soft knock at the door. (The strains of bagpi can still be heard from below). Her Majesty's DRESSER sti her head round the corner, with a calling tray of Earl Gr tea and the newspapers.
G'morning, Ma'am.
The DRESSER puts the tea and newspapers on a bedside tabl
Shall I draw the curtains?
The QUEEN's sleepy voice answers..`Please'. The DRESSER g to the window.
Did you stay up?
Yes, Ma'am.
And? Was it as expected..?
The QUEEN's hand reaches for spectacles, then for the newspapers. She puts on her glasses.
Yes, Ma'am. Mr Blair, by a landslide.
The QUEEN's expression changes..
I see.

She lifts the newspaper up. The front page comes into sha focus. FULL FRAME: the beaming smile of TONY BLAIR, the new Prim Minister. The QUEEN stares back. Their eyes meet - as it were. Headlines tell us.. "IT'S BLAIR!", "LANDSLIDE VICTORY FOR BLAIR".
The QUEEN sits at breakfast. Reading the newspapers. Dogs under the table. A knock on the door, and ROBIN JANVRIN, (40's), her deputy Private Secretary, pops around..
The Prime Minister is on his way, Ma'am.
To BE, Robin. (correcting, terse) Prime Minister to BE.
The QUEEN frostily flicks a page, without looking up.. ELIZABETH (cont'd) He hasn't asked my permission yet.
The QUEEN and JANVRIN walk through a corridor of the Pala It has the air of a grand hotel. Chintz. Flock. Long, gil mirrors. Portraits on the walls..
He's a hard one to read, isn't he?
Yes. On the one hand his background is quite establishment. Father a Conservative. A public school education at Fettes, where he was tutored by the same man as the Prince of Wales.
Well, we'll try not to hold that against him.
On the other, his manifesto promises the most radical modernisation and shake-up of the Constitution in three hundred years.
Oh. Is he going to `modernise' us, do you think?
I wouldn't put it past him. He's married to a woman with known anti- Monarchist sympathies - you may remember her curtsey the first time you met. It could best be described as `shallow'.
I don't measure the depth of a curtsey, Robin. I leave that to my sister.
And I spoke to the Cabinet Secretary who said he was expecting the atmosphere at Downing Street to be very informal. Everyone on first name terms. (a beat) At the Prime Minister's insistence.
What? As in `Call me Tony?'
Yes.
The QUEEN's face puckers in distaste..
Oh. I'm not sure I like the sound of that. (a beat) Have we sent him a protocol sheet?
ARCHIVE FOOTAGE: as TONY BLAIR's motorcade drives down th MALL.
The motorcade sweeps into the grand, inner quadrangle of Buckingham Palace, and stops at the King's door.
Three secret service BODYGUARDS leap out and open the car doors. TONY looks out at the palace..
Funny, I'm actually rather nervous.
hy? You've met her often enough before.
I know. But never one to one. And never as Prime Minister.
Remember, you're a man that's just been elected by the whole country.
Yes. But she's still, y'know..
TONY looks up at the vast palace in front of him..
The Queen.
A uniformed EQUERRY leads TONY and CHERIE through corrido and up a grand staircase..

When we reach the audience room, I will knock. We will not wait to be called, we will go straight inside. Standing by the door, we bow. From the neck. I will introduce you. The Queen will extend her hand, you go to her, bow again, then shake her hand.
TONY shoots his cuffs, `Right', clears his throat. QUERRY (cont'd) Couple of other things. It's `Ma'am' as in ham, not Ma'am as in farm.
Yes..
And when you're in the Presence, at no point must you show your back.
The `Presence'?
Yes, Sir. That's what it's called, when you're in her Majesty's company.

TONY turns, shoots a look at CHERIE, who sticks her finge down her throat. TONY smiles back.. The EQUERRY reaches a grand door, and knocks gently. With waiting for a reply, he enters.. CHERIE is left in the corridor. Alone. She stares at a liveried FOOTMAN. He stares back. No life behind his eyes. CHERIE takes a s on a chair. Eyes widen to herself.
TONY and the EQUERRY enter, and gently bow their heads. T EQUERRY then straightens, and announces..
Mr Blair, your Majesty.
The QUEEN extends her hand. TONY walks forward, and shake it. The EQUERRY leaves. The door is then closed.
ongratulations.
Thank you, Ma'am.
Your children must be very proud.
I hope so.
You've three, haven't you?
That's right.
How lovely. Such a blessing. Children.
The QUEEN and TONY take their seats..
So..Have we shown you how to start a nuclear war yet?
(thrown) No.
First thing we do, I believe. a beat) Then we take your passport and spend the rest of the time sending you around the world.
You obviously know my job better than I do.

Well, you are my tenth Prime Minister, Mr Blair. I'd like to think there weren't too many surprises left. My first was Winston Churchill. He sat in your chair, in frock coat and top hat, and was kind enough to give a shy
young girl like me quite an education.
I can imagine.

ith time, one has hopefully added experience to that education, and a little wisdom - better enabling us to execute our constitutional responsibility. (a pointed addition) To advise, guide and warn the government of the day.
Advice which I look forward to receiving.
ell, we will save that for our weekly meetings. a beat) Now, if there's nothing else, I believe we have some business to attend to..
TONY stares, then clicks..
Of course..
He falls, rather extravagantly, on bended knee. The supplicant position of deference...
Your Majesty, the country has spoken...and I come now to ask your permiss..   E
(interjecting) No, no, no. It's usual for ME to ask the questions.
TONY winces. Wishes the ground would swallow him up.
Mr Blair, the people have elected you to be their leader. And so the duty falls on me, as your Sovereign, to ask you to become Prime Minister, and form a government in my name.
TONY stares. Lost for words. Then..
Generally, this is where you say `yes.'
`Yes'.

The QUEEN extends her hand, which TONY kisses. She withdr it again - quite sharply, then DISCREETLY PRESSES A BUZZE her chair indicating the ceremony is over. The EQUERRY op a door, and CHERIE is invited inside. ELIZABETH (cont'd) How nice to see you again, Mrs Blair.
HERIE curtseys awkwardly, reluctantly, shallowly.. ELIZABETH (cont'd) You must be very proud.
Yes.
And exhausted, I imagine. Where will you be spending the summer?
France.
How lovely.
ou'll be in Balmoral, I expect.
Yes, I can hardly wait. Wonderful place.
The QUEEN indicates a portrait of QUEEN VICTORIA..
My great, great grandmother said of it - "In Balmoral all seems to breathe freedom and peace and to make one forget the world and its sad turmoils."
t that moment, the doors open, and JANVRIN enters, and whispers urgently in the QUEEN's ear. The QUEEN's face changes as she listens. ELIZABETH (cont'd) Really..?
Her expression changes. She frostily turns to the BLAIRS. ELIZABETH (cont'd) I'm afraid we're going to have to leave it there.
With that the QUEEN shakes TONY's hand. TONY and CHERIE awkwardly back out of the royal presence, leaving The QUE and JANVRIN.
Not too short, was it? I gave him fifteen minutes. (a beat) One doesn't want to be rude.
TONY and CHERIE walk down a corridor. CHERIE whispers und her breath..
(mimics QUEEN's manner) "Thank you so much for coming. Now bugger off."
I know. What was all that about?
Diana. Apparently she's got a new boyfriend.
Of PRINCESS DIANA walking hand in hand with a dark-haired in his late thirties..
Dodi Al-Fayed is the son of Egyptian millionaire Mohammed Al-Fayed, a man whom the English establishment has repeatedly denied a British passport..
DIANA and DODI kissing and canoodling on board the yacht `Jonikal'..
The Princess and Mr Fayed were hugging and kissing in full view of the world's press yesterday..
DIANA and DODI on the yacht on their last holiday togethe
..the couple then left for Paris. At one point, the Princess told gathered reporters to watch out. Her next move would really surprise them...
PAPARAZZI are assembled outside the hotel. A few SPECTATO too. CAPTION: "RITZ HOTEL, PARIS. 31 AUGUST, 1997". Various NEWS REPORTERS are also broadcasting...
(in French) ..the Princess of Wales and Dodi Fayed returned to Paris earlier today..
..where they visited a local jewellery shop where unconfirmed reports suggested Mr Fayed had been looking at engagement rings..
CCTV FOOTAGE: the unmistakable blonde hair of the PRINCES WALES as she enters the Ritz Hotel through revolving door
German REPORTER continues..
(in German) ...they have now been inside the hotel for more than two hours. We believe they have been dining in a suite on the fifth floor..
Presently a ripple of activity: DOORMEN furtively speak i walkie-talkies. Growing anticipation in the CROWD.. An AMERICAN REPORTER turns to his camera..
We've just been told the Princess is about to come out of the hotel..
PAPARAZZI jostle roughly for position, and raise their cameras as the doors open, and a BLACK MERCEDES slides in position.
Elsewhere in the hotel.. The real DIANA, her BODYGUARD, DODI FAYED, and HENRI PAUL leave the public part of the hotel, and walk down a fligh stairs..

Pandemonium breaks out as BODYGUARDS emerge from the hote Engines roar into life of the decoy black Mercedes. Doors slam. The CROWD surges. An explosion of flashlights Tyres burn. The squeal of rubber as the MERCEDES pulls of Swarms of PAPARAZZI give chase, kick-starting their motorcycles, speaking into cell-phones to their COLLEAGUE
The real ROYAL PARTY, meanwhile, walks briskly through an underground corridor which leads to the back door of the hotel..

PAPARAZZI who were waiting at the back exit, speak to the COLLEAGUES on their cell phones, and are about to jump on their motorcycles to join them in the chase, when suddenl HENRI PAUL, PRINCESS DIANA, her BODYGUARD and DODI FAYED emerge from a door, and climb into a waiting Mercedes. HE PAUL turns to the PAPARAZZI..
(in French, we see sub- titles) Don't bother following. You won't catch us.
The engine starts with a roar. The PAPARAZZI double-take, frantically shout into their phones to their COLLEAGUES. `Wait! They've come out at the back.'

The Mercedes pulls up at a traffic light. ALL AROUND THEM: the glare of Paparazzi motorcycles and camera flashbulbs around the car. The Paparazzi call out French and Italian. They thump the window. It's terrifyin An explosion of flashing lights. Popping flashbulbs. The traffic light turns amber. DODI barks at the DRIVER.. The DRIVER, a short squat man in glasses, (we do not see face), slams his foot down.
The car roars ahead, then speeds down into a tunnel, foll by the PAPARAZZI MOTORCYCLES.
The Scottish Highlands. To establish.
The silhouette of a magnificent ten year old STAG stands rock, and roars into the night.
`RRRRrrrinnnnggg', the phone rings.. A SILHOUETTE fumbles for a light switch, and hits the lig We immediately recognise the face. It's JANVRIN, the Quee deputy Private Secretary.
(into PHONE) Robin Janvrin.
He listens, then his expression changes. ANVRIN (cont'd) What?
He checks the clock on the bedside table, waking rapidly Deadly serious.. ANVRIN (cont'd) Right. I see.
JANVRIN hangs up. Then urgently dials a number on the telephone..
JANVRIN (cont'd) I'm going to need to speak to her Majesty. Right away.
till pulling on clothes, JANVRIN rushes on foot towards t big house in the distance. Lights go on all over the dark castle.

ANVRIN and a middle-aged   DRESSER, (half-asleep and stil rearranging her uniform),   walk urgently up the stairs t the second floor corridor   where the QUEEN's bedroom is located. They pass a PAGE   on the way down..
Tell Sir Guy I'd like everyone in. As soon as possible.
The PAGE nods. Departs.
A knock on the door. The door opens, and the DRESSER's vo gently calls out..
Ma'am?
he QUEEN stirs in her bed..
Mr Janvrin is here to see you..
Oh..
The QUEEN turns on the light. The DUKE of EDINBURGH flinc in irritation, scrunching his eyes as they are blinded..
What the..?
he QUEEN emerges from her bedroom wearing an old-fashione dressing-gown, and clutching a hottie, (a velour-covered Cosimax hot water bottle), to find ROBIN JANVRIN waiting.
Good evening, Ma'am. I'm sorry to disturb..
He clears his throat..
I 've just had a call from our Embassy in Paris. It's...the Princess of Wales.
PRINCE PHILIP appears in the doorway. Irritable.
Why? What's she done now?

"Rrrrrinng", the phone rings. We're in TONY BLAIR's constituency house in Trimdon, near Durham in northern England. Click', TONY, in T-shirt, turns on the light. His face is creased with sleep. He blinks..
What? How badly?
The figure of CHERIE stirs in the bed. Groans. TONY liste to the voice at the other end..
I see. Who are we speaking to there?
Right. shell-shocked) Keep me posted.
TONY hangs up. CHERIE turns..
It's Diana. She's been in a car accident. In Paris.
Is it serious?
Apparently Dodi Fayed is dead.
What?
CHERIE's face. Visibly shocked.   TONY has switched on th in the bedroom.
Let's just re-cap on what's happened.
he QUEEN is sitting with the DUKE OF EDINBURGH.
What was she doing in Paris?
ou know what she's like.

The QUEEN flicks channels, peering over her glasses, tryi to catch the latest news on the television.. At that moment CHARLES enters the room. His face ravaged concern. It's the first time the QUEEN has seen him since news of the crisis..
It's quite awful... (wants to console CHARLES but finds it easier to say..) What are you going to do about the boys?
An awkward moment. Stifled..
Let them sleep until we know more.
Yes that's sensible.
I should go to Paris. I told my people to start organising a jet.
What? A private one?
Yes.
Isn't that precisely the sort of extravagance they attack us for?
ell, how else am I going to get to Paris at this time of night? The airport at Aberdeen will be closed.
Presently, a voice from behind..
You can use the Royal Flight. They keep one of the planes on permanent stand-by. deadpans) In case I kick the bucket.
Out of the question. It's not a matter of State.
What are you talking about?
Diana is no longer an HRH, nor a member of the Royal Family. This is a private matter.
She's mother to your grandchildren.
The QUEEN MOTHER sits on the sofa next to PRINCE PHILIP..
That's the latest?
I don't know. I can't hear.. (indicates TELEVISION) Everyone's shouting!
CHARLES stares in disbelief. Exits the room..
television plays in the corner..
..behind me, is the tunnel of the Pont de l'Alma, which you reach by the expressway along the Seine. It was along here that the Mercedes carrying the Princess..
ANVRIN's SECRETARY hands over the phone..
The Ambassador, in Paris.
Good evening, Sir.
JANVRIN listens to what the person is saying at the other end. His expression changes..
Right. ashen-faced) I see.
An ashen-faced JANVRIN walks along the corridor, reaches room where the ROYAL FAMILY is watching television. e clears his throat, knocks on the door..
JANVRIN enters.
I've just spoken to our Ambassador in Paris, Ma'am.
ll heads turn to face him.. JANVRIN (cont'd) I'm afraid it's not good news.
PRINCE CHARLES's face: he lets out a strangled cry, as he hears the news..
No!
CHARLES roars in pain and disbelief. His knuckles whiten.
No, no, no, no..!
In the doorway: STEPHEN LAMPORT, who has delivered the ne can hardly bear to watch..
ON TV: struggling in vain to hold onto his composure, a BRITISH NEWSREADER relays the news, visibly in shock..
We have just had confirmation, that
Diana, Princess of Wales.. voice cracks) ..has died in Paris.
ELIZABETH, PRINCE PHILIP and THE QUEEN MOTHER all stare. tableau of shock. CNN ANCHOR breaks the news to a worldwide audience..
"I'm afraid we have some bad news to report.."
The CNN ANCHOR continues on TV.
"Diana, Princess of Wales, is dead."
TONY BLAIR is watching on TV, sitting downstairs, having thrown on some clothes. He speaks on the phone..
What have I got on this week?
ALASTAIR CAMPBELL, Press Secretary to TONY BLAIR, is dres and already in Downing Street. Also watching television. INTERCUT BETWEEN THE TWO LOCATIONS AS NECESSARY).
You're writing your maiden Conference speech as Prime Minister.
Well, let's cancel everything else. This is going to be massive. a beat) I'd better make a statement in the morning.
You'll be pleased to know I've already started coming up with ideas.
n CAMPBELL's knee, a pad of paper. We pick out the words, "People's Princess." T
God, she's only been dead an hour!
Would you prefer I didn't do my job?

he QUEEN's FACE in close-up. Her eyes flicker as she watc something intently. e REVERSE ANGLE to see: a half-open door. SILHOUETTES inside. The sound of male voices. Whispering. Speaking softly. It's the moment the BOYS are being told. We make out the SILHOUETTES hugging. The sound of tears. Soft voices. CHA repeatedly kissing his SONS. ur CAMERA stays on the QUEEN's FACE. A distant flicker of pain at the unrestrained intimacy and affection between t Presently, the door opens, and a red-eyed PRINCE CHARLES emerges.
They're going to go back to sleep. (clears his throat, speaks with difficulty) Well, try anyway.
The QUEEN goes up to CHARLES and stiffly, poignantly, tri to touch him. But cannot. Is unable. She withdraws her ha
(reading the message) My Private Secretary's office has found a travel agency open in New York that will sell me a flight to Paris with an hour's stop over in Manchester.
CHARLES contains himself with difficulty..
Perhaps now you might consider whether it's still an extravagance to bring back the mother of the future King of England in one of our planes?
(after a long pause) All right.
HARLES's eyes burn. He turns, and walks out. The QUEEN is left alone. She stares for a moment, then leaves, passing a FOOTMAN.
(to FOOTMAN) I don't want the boys to see the news and get upset. First thing tomorrow morning, I want the radio taken out of their bedroom, and the television taken out of the nursery.
The FOOTMAN bows..
The QUEEN sits in bed, writing her diary, in a bedchamber where the decor is unchanged in a hundred years..
utside, the sound of bird-song. The first rays of light. The DUKE OF EDINBURGH sticks his head around the corner. looks at the QUEEN..
Well, well, well.
Ye-es.
Are you all right?
A silence. PRINCE PHILIP (cont'd) Your sister called about an hour ago. From Tuscany.
hope you told her to come back? Cut the holiday short?
I did.
ELIZABETH raises her eyebrow..
an't imagine she was pleased.
That's putting it mildly.
What did she say?
PHILIP smiles to himself recalling MARGARET's words..
Something about Diana managing to be even more annoying dead than alive.
The QUEEN looks up..
Just make sure the boys never hear you talk like that.
Of course.
PHILIP produces a bottle of pills from his dressing-gown pocket, and shakes them.. PRINCE PHILIP (cont'd) Something to help you go down?
No. I'm going to do my diary a little longer.
Fine. I'll sleep next door.

PHILIP touches her on the shoulder. But she doesn't reciprocate. He goes. The QUEEN appears to continue writi but our CAMERA slowly turns to reveal her PEN is not movi Nor writing. She's staring in thought.

Victorian, red-brick house. In the driveway, the incongruous mix of a grey Renault Espace people-carrier a two POLICE VEHICLES. In the modest garden: two ARMED POLICE OFFICERS are playi football with three young CHILDREN..

Inside the plain, unfashionably decorated house.. The TV plays in the corner of the kitchen. CHERIE BLAIR, visibly upset, watches TV while cooking breakfast. TONY is not wearing his Newcastle shirt. TONY is reading out his statement which is written on a p of paper, filled with crossings-out..
"..that's how she will remain. In our minds, our hearts, forever." (looks up) OK, got it.
ALASTAIR CAMPBELL is in Downing Street, sits in an office feet on a desk, staring at the TV..
Where will you do it?
I thought at church. On the way in.
ON TV: breaking news: Diana's brother, EARL SPENCER, make statement from the gates outside his house in South Afric
...this is not a time for recriminations, however I would say that I always believed that the press would kill her in the end.

SPENCER(cont'd) But even I could not imagine that they would take such a direct hand in her death as seems to be the case. It would appear that every proprietor and editor of every publication that has paid for intrusive and exploitative photographs of her has blood on his hands today...
Not the press, mate. You've got the wrong villain.
An AIDE appears in the doorway, catches TONY's eye, and indicates her watch..
I've got to go.
You about to speak to the Queen?
Yes.
ALASTAIR shoots a mischievous look..
Ask her if SHE greased the brakes.
Now, now..
TONY hangs up, crosses to the study, making sure the door are shut so he won't be disturbed. We notice his shirt ha no. 10 on the back, under the name, `BLAIR'.

he QUEEN, PRINCE PHILIP and the QUEEN MOTHER sit in silen at the table, eating breakfast, stoically listening to ra coverage, soberly flicking through newspapers.. The QUEEN is the only one who is fully dressed, (the othe in bathrobes), and she wears black. She is reading "The Sunday Times". All around them the QUEEN's (elderly) MAIDS perform the choreography of service as the radio coverage continues. MAID pours tea. Another brings fresh toast. Also present is the rather smarter VALET and MAID belongi to the PRINCE of WALES, and his separate HOUSEHOLD. They a separate, (and more stylish), uniform of their own.
hey set CHARLES's place and his breakfast, (nuts, grains, healthy food).

A flamboyant napkin is folded into an elaborate fleur-du- (traditional symbol of the PRINCE OF WALES). The QUEEN tu to Charles's VALET.. A knock on the door, JANVRIN enters, and bows in respect the QUEEN..
I'm sorry to disturb, Ma'am, but I've the Prime Minister, for you. From his constituency.
(privately rolls eyes, without looking up from newspaper) Lucky you.
Thank you, Robin. I'll take it next door.
he QUEEN gets to her feet and walks out into..
The first-floor corridor. STAFF flatten themselves agains the wall, averting their eyes as.. The QUEEN unexpectedly comes out of the dining-room, walk along the corridor, and disappears into..
The QUEEN's study. High ceilings, portraits, stag's antle on the wall. The QUEEN picks up the phone.. ELIZABETH (cont'd) Good morning, Prime Minister.
The contrast in surroundings could hardly be greater. TON sitting in a cramped room, surrounded by toys, in track s in a working-class house..
Good morning, your Majesty. May I say right away how very sorry I am - and that the thoughts and prayers of my family are with you at this terrible time and with the two princes in particular.
Thank you.
HERIE appears in the doorway.
Is it your intention to make some kind of appearance. Or statement?
Certainly not.
The QUEEN's face, bristling at the suggestion. (WE INTERC AS NECESSARY)..
No member of the Royal family will speak publicly about this. It is a private matter and we would all appreciate it if it could be respected as such.
I see.
TONY straightens, taken aback..
I don't suppose anyone has had time to think about the funeral yet?
We've spoken to the Spencer family, and it's their wish.. (a beat) ..their express wish, that it should be a private funeral. With a memorial service to follow in a month, or so.
Right.
TONY shoots a look at CHERIE..
Given that Diana was no longer a member of the Royal Family we have no choice but to respect their wishes.
I see.
TONY shoots a look at CHERIE..
You don't feel that in view of her high profile and popularity..
choosing his words carefully) ...it might be an idea to pay tribute to her life and achievements? (a beat) Or even just to her as a mother?
The QUEEN's face freezes over.
As I said. That's the Spencers' wish. TONY (cont'd) And the public, Ma'am? The British People?
TONY hesitates..
You don't think a private funeral would be denying them a chance..
hance to what..?
To share in the grief?
The QUEEN's face: did she hear right?
It's a family funeral, Mr. Blair. Not a fairground attraction. (a beat) I think the Princess has already paid a high enough price for exposure to the press, don't you?
PRINCE PHILIP enters, dressed and ready for church. He indicates his watch.. ELIZABETH (cont'd) Now, if there is nothing else I must get on. The children have to be looked after.
Of course.
`Click', the QUEEN hangs up. TONY stares at the receiver. TONY (cont'd) Good bye, Your Majesty.
He puts down the phone...
Her instinct is to do nothing. Say nothing. And give her a private funeral.
Are you surprised? She hated her guts.
Well, I think it's a mistake.
TONY's face becomes dark..
They screwed up her life. Let's hope they don't screw up her death.
veryone is getting ready to go to church. The QUEEN and QUEEN MOTHER are putting on their hats. PRINCE PHILIP, in full Highland regalia and black tie, helps both LADIES in their long coats...
The Chaplain called. Wanted to know whether he should make any changes to the service or make special mention of Diana.
What did you say?
I told him he shouldn't change a thing.
Q uite right.
I think the less fuss one makes, or draws attention to it, the better. she lowers her voice, as the PRINCES approach from the saloon with CHARLES) For the boys.
Yes.
And we should probably arrange some company for them. Some young people.
I'll take them for a long walk this afternoon. Up Craggy Head.
Good. They'd like that.
RINCE PHILIP opens the doors.. ELIZABETH (cont'd) But no guns. It's Sunday.
They walk off to the waiting CARS..
Offices BUSY FOR SUNDAY. Bustling AIDES and SECRETARIES. engine room of Government. An AIDE sticks his head round door, and calls down the corridor to...
Alastair? He's on..
CAMPBELL turns, and excuses himself from his conversation walks back down the corridor..

ALASTAIR enters a press `monitoring' room, where several televisions are playing. One or two AIDES are busy workin ON TV: TONY, wearing a dark suit, and tie, takes his posi in front of the statue of the Virgin Mary, in front of th cameras.
TONY steps closer to the microphones, then..
e are today a nation in a state of shock, in mourning, in grief that is so deeply painful to us. People everywhere, not just here in Britain, kept faith with Princess Diana..
JANVRIN watches the broadcast on television, surrounded b several MEMBERS OF STAFF - MAIDS, COOKS, VALETS, FOOTMEN, craning their necks, watching the television in the Priva Secretary's room..
Our camera stays on JANVRIN's face, as TONY's speech continues..
